Barclays:

11:15 am
BE11:16am

TCG has 1) announced a £200m seasonal standby facility, on top of the previously announced £900m of capital injection, and 2) reiterated that the recapitalisation is expected to result in existing shareholders’ interests being significantly diluted, with “significant risk of no recovery”. We note that the final comment is incremental from previous statements. Since our last report M&A support, is it enough? (11/6/19), the shares have declined 79% from 19p to 4p. There has been a huge amount of newsflow (key news summarised below) which highlights the complexity of the recapitalisation and negotiations with multiple parties. The investment case, therefore, remains extremely opaque and TCG continues to sit squarely in the special situation bucket. While we are EW on both TUI (PT 900p) and TCG (PT 17p), we have a relevant preference for TUI.

Summarising the newsflow - since mid-June there have been multiple developments, most significantly: (i) TCG has announced the targeted injection of £750m of capital and financing facilities, conversion of the majority of debt-for-equity, and proposed separation of the Airline and Tour Op (12-Jul-19); (ii) an additional capital injection of £150m (12-Aug-19); (iii) the split of capital injection between Fosun and core lending banks and noteholders (£450m each) and split of ownership once the business is separated (28-Aug-19); and (iv) an additional seasonal standby facility of £200m (announced today). There has also been much media speculation including: Sky news reporting that Tomas Cook is in talks to offload its Nordic airline and tour op in a fire-sale (20 September 2019, see link), The Times reported that the UK CAA is making Contingency plans for TCG’s collapse (15 September 2019, see link) and German newspaper Handelsblatt reported that TUI / Condor have entered talks to integrate Condor into a JV with another partner within which TUIfly would take a minority stake (16 September 2019, see link). The TUI CEO has often mentioned that overcapacity in the German airline market is a structural headwind. If integration of Condor into a JV would result in reduced capacity in the German airline market then we think this would be a net positive for TUI.

cheeckychappy @BE - once your done with the corporate can you do some DPL?
BE11:17am

Stifel:

BE11:17am

The worst case scenario is failure to agree a recapitalisation plan resulting in administration of some or all parts of the business. This would lead to significant disruption for the industry and, longer-term, a more benign competitive backdrop for the likes of TUI, Dart, On the Beach

As an aside, it's a difficult one for the government. King reporting just now that RBS are one of the ones putting pressure on the business to raise this extra £200m. RBS is part government owned, so indirectly, or directly (via getting passengers home) the government will be picking up some of the tab.

2s10s @marktime: I really like September weather like this, the sea are warm, the days are not too long, no threat of oppressive heat, just lovely.

UK investment bank suffering.

BE11:24am

Here's James Hamilton at Numis to talk us through it all.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Adjusted EPS is expected to be 4-7% lower than last year, despite credit quality remaining robust, AuM increased by 6.7% to £178.4bn with net inflows of £3.5bn in Asset Management. Profits from the Wealth business have reduced, with the UK specialist bank seeing profits fall significantly, despite a 4.7% increase in the loan book. Investment Banking and Markets were weaker.

Forester Ahhhh putting the square to bed....bit like shutting up the East wing of the house for winter - reassuring.
BE11:25am

Investec has a very diversified and global Asset Management business, which now has AuM of £178.6bn. Of the UK listed Asset Managers, it is probably most similar to Schroders, with more of an Africa bias. Long-term performance is good and net flows have been consistently strong. Investec has built this business organically from scratch, creating a substantial amount of shareholder value along the way. The Wealth business has largely been built through acquisitions, which have consistently been made at the right time of the cycle and have been delivering substantial synergies. The business is very UK biased and it is most similar to Rathbones, although it is larger and more profitable. Organic net flows have also been consistently strong and this business is currently building an online capability that we believe will vastly surpass anything that any of the other Wealth Managers has to offer clients. While Asset & Wealth account for less than 39.5% of the group's profit, we estimate that they account for 61% of the group's valuation.

marktime So a podcast is a normal tv programme but the presenters wear big headphones in a sound studio order to ...

Quite a lot going on here in the trading statement:

JP11:27am

The UK Specialist Banking business is expected to report adjusted operating profit significantly behind the prior period. Market variability and persistent uncertainty relating to Brexit and global trade wars, has negatively impacted investment banking fees and trading income. Furthermore, interest income has been impacted by the additional liquidity required to pre-fund the exit of Irish deposits as a result of Brexit. However, our lending franchises have continued to perform as expected. The corporate lending and private banking businesses have shown traction in both target client acquisition, fee income and loan book growth with the total UK loan book growing 4.7% since 31 March 2019 (to GBP11.0 billion). Management's focus on cost discipline, as well as lower premises charges, are expected to result in a marked reduction in costs.

Irish HF guy @YourGrannyOnBongos, they sell technology solutions to the train operating companies to allow ticket purchases online, and take a fee of £1 per ticket and commission on the ticket sale. They also operate the trainline.com which is a train ticket app. I noticed that Irish Ferries have outsourced their UK to Ireland train tickets (with the ferry obviously) to trainline.com. You may ask why do people not book directly, in a lot of cases tourists and occassional travelers do not know the operating entity on a particular route, hence trainline just let them book online conveniently. Rich valuation, but similar to ocado, all things online are wonderful.

Rolls-Royce announced this morning that the return to single-digit levels of AOGs (aircraft on ground) on the Trent 1000 will now be delayed until 2Q 2020. The extended recovery period is being attributed to additional Maintenance Repair & Overhaul load since the 1H results. The guidance for cash costs on the Package B and C in-service issues in 2019 and 2020 remains unchanged from first-half results.

BE11:41am

And Jefferies, because when it's an aerospace company the law says you have to quote Sandy Morris.

BE11:41am

The IPT blade [on the Norwegian Boeing 787 that went pop over Rome] failed 200 cycles before it was mandated to be replaced under the related EASA AD. Since then, we perceived a risk that further action would be required, potentially leading to higher costs being incurred. In that sense, today's announcement that guidance for the Trent 1000 cash costs in 2019 and 2020 remains unchanged comes as a relief to us.

Irish HF guy Trainline market cap £2.1bn for an entity that just about makes £60m adjusted EBITDA and after finance costs loses money. The business model is low margin and costs a lot to have infrastructure etc. Operating profit was £11m for 12m to Feb 2019. @JP, it is trading at 10x LTM revenues and the ROTR all know about the 10x revenues quotx ce recently posted here. They did generate £72m in cash flow so only 29x cash flow
JP11:44am

Here you go:

11:45 am
JP11:45am

Outperformance not sustainable. Risk vs reward skewed to the downside
ANTO is the best performing large-cap copper stock over the last 12m and has outperformed the copper price by ~15%. In our view this outperformance is partially justified by ANTO's positive operational momentum in 2019 combined with trustworthy management that have delivered a consistent message. But in a deteriorating macro environment in our view structural copper bulls have also prioritised 'low risk' copper exposure and this accentuated ANTO's outperformance. We see a balanced copper price outlook into 2020 (Link) but with the stock up ~20% over the last month vs flat copper price we see downside risk to the shares with headwinds from: (1) Higher capex resulting in negative FCF at spot. (2) Lower copper production & higher costs in 2020.

XYZed Metro roadshowing bond placing this week - important for meeting reg reqs
JP11:46am

Consensus capex for 2020 looks too low……
At 1H19 results (Link) ANTO suggested FY20 capex would remain below $1.5bn. But at a CEO roundtable in Sept (Link) ANTO provided a breakdown of estimated FY20 capex ($750-800m sustaining/development + $600-700m LosP expansion + $150-200m other), implying $1.5-1.7bn. FY20 budgets have not been finalised but the $1.5-1.7bn estimate is higher than current Bloomberg consensus at $1.25bn (UBSe $1.5bn).

hornblower @Irish - I used Omio to go to Manchester and it was £40 cheaper than Trainline. Trainline at 58x!!
JP11:46am

Lower grades/production in 2020 is expected….but is still a headwind
In our view ANTO has delivered a consistent message over the last 12m that they expect grades to decline in 2020 resulting in lower production and slightly higher cash costs. ANTO expects FY20 copper production to be above FY18 (725kt) but below FY19 (750-790kt); we forecast production of 745kt implying a small (3%) y/y production decline.

nightingale20201 lets hope mgt of ANTO does not go down the same path of FRES....the latter has just delivered 3 disappointments in a row (in the last 10 years)
11:47 am

Valuation: Sell (vs neutral) £8.5/sh target based on 50:50 EV/EBITDA & P/NPV
ANTO offers 'clean' copper exposure but after outperformance (vs copper price & peers) in our view its valuation looks stretched (even by ANTO's standards) with spot (US$2.63/lb) 2020 EV/EBITDA of ~8.5x (3 year average ~7x), 30x PE and negative FCF

Macquarie:

BE11:51am

The company expects flat rolled segment result to be negatively impacted by
falling steel and scrap prices and plans to keep the two blast furnaces idled
through the end of the year. The European and Tubular segments remain under
pressure in challenging market conditions. Overall, we are seeing weakening
results across all segments and hence believe USS could burn over $1 billion of
cash unless the steel market supply demand dynamics significantly improve.
 Steel price momentum has reversed on lack of demand growth and the fact that
scrap prices are expected to stay weak towards the end of the year. In addition,
lead times for hot rolled coil have fallen below four weeks. As for downstream
demand, buyers are sitting on the sidelines on expectations of weakening demand,
as suggested by contracting manufacturing PMI, lower rig counts, falling auto sales
and the fact that non-residential construction spending has started to slow down.

BE11:55am

Burberry is the largest brand of all turnaround stories and brand heat has seen rising strongly of late. New collections will account for the majority of sales from 2QFY20 and we expect LFL to accelerate to +6% from +4% in 1QFY20. We raise our FY21e and FY22e LFL to +8% from +6% previously. Despite likely margin reinvestment to support brand momentum, additional operating leverage leads to a 3% and 7% increase to our FY21e and FY22e operating profit estimates, which are 4% and 12% above consensus. At 22x CY20e P/E, on our numbers, against our coverage at 23x, we believe a discount is unwarranted at this stage of the brand cycle. The main risks include China macro and brand heat quickly falling.

BE12:00pm

Over the last two months, the shares have fallen over 30%. Consequently we upgrade our recommendation to Hold from Sell. There are no changes to our forecasts which remain above consensus for FY19, we suspect due to a transition to IFRS 15, but remain below consensus for FY20 and beyond.

However, our target price is decreased reflecting a discount to our peer group of 10%

In our initiation note dated 2nd August we commented that our target price "at best" was 1175p. We decrease this today, believing that the shares should more fairly trade at a c10% discount to our peer group, rather than at an average, given the differences of 1) higher forecast losses, 2) higher price deflation in the RPA sub-sector and 3) a higher level of DSOs.

A table of the peer group average EV/sales values for their respective periods of highest growth is shown below. At a 10% discount to the average of 6.8x, this implies an annualised EV to December 2019 of c6.1x on annualised sales to December 19 of £110m. This leads to an EV of around £670m and our target price of 1050p.
